SANATORIUMS 401
The Sanatorium
Hudson, Wisconsin
19 Miles East of St. Paul, on Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis & Omaha Ry.
T
One of the most delightfully located and fully equipped institutions in the United
States for care and treatment of invalids, and of rest for the tired and worn-out.
ALL FORMS OF TREATMENT
Turkish, Russian, Electric, Saline and Plain Baths,
Massage and Movement Cures,
Electricity Employed in all its Forms.
EXPERIENCED PHYSICIANS
TRAINED NURSES
Gymnasium, Parlors, Electric Lights, Fine Elevator. Building heated
by hot water and Steam; ventilated by steam fan. Solarium. In winter all
verandas are inclosed in glass, making a delightful promenade.
SPECIAL ATTENTION GIVEN TO DIETARY
For further information address,
The Sanatorium
Hudson,
3
Wisconsin

The Association of American Directory Publishers is composed
of reputable City Directory Publishers; organized for the general
advancement of the Directory business. Any person, corporation
or firm engaged in business as owner and publisher of a City
Directory in the United States or Canada, who shall qualify as.
competent to gather information and compile a City Directory and
furnish satisfactory references, is eligible to membership.
The objects of the Association are:
First. The advancement of the Directory business and the
improvement of Directories by the interchange of ideas and the
exchange of experienced employes.
Second. To provide protection to the public against fraudulent
advertising schemes which operate under the name of Directories, and to
drive unprincipled promoters of the same out of the business.
Third. To provide permanent and profitable employment to
competent, industrious and honest Directory canvassers and compilers.
Fourth. For the mutual protection and advancement of the
established and prospective interests of all who may become mem-
bers, by personal advice and assistance of members as may be
mutually satisfactory, desirable or advisable, and by such other means
as may, from time to time, be shown to be wise, proper and lawful.
$100.00 Reward
Will be paid by the Association
for the arrest and conviction of
any person or persons engaged
in publishing, collecting or canvassing for any fraudulent
or fake Directory.

INTRODUCTORY
1910
We present this, our thirty-eighth edition of the Minneapolis Direct-
ory, to our friends, patrons-and the general public, with the utmost confi-
dence in its worth as a work of reference, and as a true exponent of this
great city concerning its population and business.
To our patrons who have made this work possible we express our
thanks, and they deserve the thanks of every inhabitant of this great city,
for a good directory is of the utmost importance to a city's welfare, but
we wish also to congratulate them for, in exchange for their patronage,
we have given them a representation and prominence over non-patrons.
which we feel is worth much more than the cost in every case.
We congratulate the people of our city on their prosperity which
is evidenced on every hand, their immense new store and office buildings,
some just finished, others nearing completion; the number of elegant flats
and beautiful residences built in the past year to accommodate the increas-
ing population and the figures which prove the ever upward growth of
trade.
Minneapolis Flour Mills produced in 1909 15,120,000 barrels of flour.
Minneapolis Bank Clearings for 1909 footed $1,029,000,000.
Minneapolis Postoffice Receipts for 1909 footed $1,828,000.
Minneapolis Building Permits for 1909 numbered 6,046, amounting
in value to $13,062,545.
These are tremendous figures, but they represent facts and speak for
themselves.
This edition shows a very gratifying increase in population.
Our last book contained 140,760 names, which indicated a population
of 316,710, while this volume contains 144,570, exclusive of deaths, re-
movals and business firms, which, using our multiple of 24, indicates
a present population of 325,282, a gain of 8,572 during the past year.
MINNEAPOLIS DIRECTORY CO.
C. Wright Davison, President.
J. C. F. Ely, Treasurer and Manager.

INTRODUCTORY
1910
We present this, our thirty-eighth edition of the Minneapolis Direct-
ory, to our friends, patrons-and the general public, with the utmost confi-
dence in its worth as a work of reference, and as a true exponent of this
great city concerning its population and business.
To our patrons who have made this work possible we express our
thanks, and they deserve the thanks of every inhabitant of this great city,
for a good directory is of the utmost importance to a city's welfare, but
we wish also to congratulate them for, in exchange for their patronage,
we have given them a representation and prominence over non-patrons.
which we feel is worth much more than the cost in every case.
We congratulate the people of our city on their prosperity which
is evidenced on every hand, their immense new store and office buildings,
some just finished, others nearing completion; the number of elegant flats
and beautiful residences built in the past year to accommodate the increas-
ing population and the figures which prove the ever upward growth of
trade.
Minneapolis Flour Mills produced in 1909 15,120,000 barrels of flour.
Minneapolis Bank Clearings for 1909 footed $1,029,000,000.
Minneapolis Postoffice Receipts for 1909 footed $1,828,000.
Minneapolis Building Permits for 1909 numbered 6,046, amounting
in value to $13,062,545.
These are tremendous figures, but they represent facts and speak for
themselves.
This edition shows a very gratifying increase in population.
Our last book contained 140,760 names, which indicated a population
of 316,710, while this volume contains 144,570, exclusive of deaths, re-
movals and business firms, which, using our multiple of 24, indicates
a present population of 325,282, a gain of 8,572 during the past year.
MINNEAPOLIS DIRECTORY CO.
C. Wright Davison, President.
J. C. F. Ely, Treasurer and Manager.

INTRODUCTORY
1910
We present this, our thirty-eighth edition of the Minneapolis Direct-
ory, to our friends, patrons-and the general public, with the utmost confi-
dence in its worth as a work of reference, and as a true exponent of this
great city concerning its population and business.
To our patrons who have made this work possible we express our
thanks, and they deserve the thanks of every inhabitant of this great city,
for a good directory is of the utmost importance to a city's welfare, but
we wish also to congratulate them for, in exchange for their patronage,
we have given them a representation and prominence over non-patrons.
which we feel is worth much more than the cost in every case.
We congratulate the people of our city on their prosperity which
is evidenced on every hand, their immense new store and office buildings,
some just finished, others nearing completion; the number of elegant flats
and beautiful residences built in the past year to accommodate the increas-
ing population and the figures which prove the ever upward growth of
trade.
Minneapolis Flour Mills produced in 1909 15,120,000 barrels of flour.
Minneapolis Bank Clearings for 1909 footed $1,029,000,000.
Minneapolis Postoffice Receipts for 1909 footed $1,828,000.
Minneapolis Building Permits for 1909 numbered 6,046, amounting
in value to $13,062,545.
These are tremendous figures, but they represent facts and speak for
themselves.
This edition shows a very gratifying increase in population.
Our last book contained 140,760 names, which indicated a population
of 316,710, while this volume contains 144,570, exclusive of deaths, re-
movals and business firms, which, using our multiple of 24, indicates
a present population of 325,282, a gain of 8,572 during the past year.
MINNEAPOLIS DIRECTORY CO.
C. Wright Davison, President.
J. C. F. Ely, Treasurer and Manager.

Street and Avenue Guide
1910
EXPLANATORY.
The city is divided by the Mississippi river into parts known as West Division
(W. D.), and East Division (E. D.) Avenues and streets in the E. D. are desig-
nated S. E. (southeast), N. E. (northeast). while all streets in the W. D. are
designated N. (north), S. (south), E. (east), W. (West); Hennepin avenue to Su-
perior avenue is the dividing line between north and south and Nicollet avenue
from Grant street, the dividing line between east and west in W. D.
All streets south of Grant street, Ken wood Parkway and Superior avenue and
running parallel therewith are designated E. when east of Nicollet avenue_and
W. when west of Nicollet avenue, while the avenues are all designated S. From
Hennepin avenue up the river is N., and from Hennepin avenue down the river S.
Streets and avenues above Hennepin avenue are designated N. (north), and
those below as S. (south). The same system pertains to the E. D. up and down
the river, except numeral streets and avenues, which are marked Ñ. E. above
Central avenue and S. E. below Central avenue. The streets and avenues are
distinguished in E. D. thus: S. E. 2d st.; N. E. 2d st.; 1st av. N. E.; 1st av. S. E.
Numeral streets in W. D. south of Hennepin avenue are designated S. from S.
1st to Grant st., they are then east and west of Nicollet avenue to 54th street.
For example, E. 14th st. and W. 14th st., etc.
Numeral streets and avenues have a regular system of numbering, 100 being
allowed to each block. For example, 600 1st avenue N. would be cor. of N. 6th
st.; 729 1st avenue S., between S. 7th and 8th streets and near 8th street, and 600
S. 1st st., corner 6th avenue S.; 100 N. 6th street, corner 1st avenue N.; 100 E. 14th
street, corner 1st avenue S.; 1300 E. 24th street, corner 13th avenue S.
Central avenue and Division street are the dividing line in the E. D. between
N. E. and S. E. with the regular system of numbering on all numeral streets
and avenues.

MINNEAPOLIS DIRECTORY
1016
Street and Avenue Guide
1910
EXPLANATORY.
The city is divided by the Mississippi river into parts known as West Division
(W. D.), and East Division (E. D.) Avenues and streets in the E. D. are desig-
nated S. E. (southeast), N. E. (northeast). while all streets in the W. D. are
designated N. (north), S. (south), E. (east), W. (West); Hennepin avenue to Su-
perior avenue is the dividing line between north and south and Nicollet avenue
from Grant street, the dividing line between east and west in W. D.
All streets south of Grant street, Ken wood Parkway and Superior avenue and
running parallel therewith are designated E. when east of Nicollet avenue_and
W. when west of Nicollet avenue, while the avenues are all designated S. From
Hennepin avenue up the river is N., and from Hennepin avenue down the river S.
Streets and avenues above Hennepin avenue are designated N. (north), and
those below as S. (south). The same system pertains to the E. D. up and down
the river, except numeral streets and avenues, which are marked Ñ. E. above
Central avenue and S. E. below Central avenue. The streets and avenues are
distinguished in E. D. thus: S. E. 2d st.; N. E. 2d st.; 1st av. N. E.; 1st av. S. E.
Numeral streets in W. D. south of Hennepin avenue are designated S. from S.
1st to Grant st., they are then east and west of Nicollet avenue to 54th street.
For example, E. 14th st. and W. 14th st., etc.
Numeral streets and avenues have a regular system of numbering, 100 being
allowed to each block. For example, 600 1st avenue N. would be cor. of N. 6th
st.; 729 1st avenue S., between S. 7th and 8th streets and near 8th street, and 600
S. 1st st., corner 6th avenue S.; 100 N. 6th street, corner 1st avenue N.; 100 E. 14th
street, corner 1st avenue S.; 1300 E. 24th street, corner 13th avenue S.
Central avenue and Division street are the dividing line in the E. D. between
N. E. and S. E. with the regular system of numbering on all numeral streets
and avenues.

Street and Avenue Guide
1910
EXPLANATORY.
The city is divided by the Mississippi river into parts known as West Division
(W. D.), and East Division (E. D.) Avenues and streets in the E. D. are desig-
nated S. E. (southeast), N. E. (northeast). while all streets in the W. D. are
designated N. (north), S. (south), E. (east), W. (West); Hennepin avenue to Su-
perior avenue is the dividing line between north and south and Nicollet avenue
from Grant street, the dividing line between east and west in W. D.
All streets south of Grant street, Ken wood Parkway and Superior avenue and
running parallel therewith are designated E. when east of Nicollet avenue_and
W. when west of Nicollet avenue, while the avenues are all designated S. From
Hennepin avenue up the river is N., and from Hennepin avenue down the river S.
Streets and avenues above Hennepin avenue are designated N. (north), and
those below as S. (south). The same system pertains to the E. D. up and down
the river, except numeral streets and avenues, which are marked Ñ. E. above
Central avenue and S. E. below Central avenue. The streets and avenues are
distinguished in E. D. thus: S. E. 2d st.; N. E. 2d st.; 1st av. N. E.; 1st av. S. E.
Numeral streets in W. D. south of Hennepin avenue are designated S. from S.
1st to Grant st., they are then east and west of Nicollet avenue to 54th street.
For example, E. 14th st. and W. 14th st., etc.
Numeral streets and avenues have a regular system of numbering, 100 being
allowed to each block. For example, 600 1st avenue N. would be cor. of N. 6th
st.; 729 1st avenue S., between S. 7th and 8th streets and near 8th street, and 600
S. 1st st., corner 6th avenue S.; 100 N. 6th street, corner 1st avenue N.; 100 E. 14th
street, corner 1st avenue S.; 1300 E. 24th street, corner 13th avenue S.
Central avenue and Division street are the dividing line in the E. D. between
N. E. and S. E. with the regular system of numbering on all numeral streets
and avenues.

MINNEAPOLIS DIRECTORY
1016
Street and Avenue Guide
1910
EXPLANATORY.
The city is divided by the Mississippi river into parts known as West Division
(W. D.), and East Division (E. D.) Avenues and streets in the E. D. are desig-
nated S. E. (southeast), N. E. (northeast). while all streets in the W. D. are
designated N. (north), S. (south), E. (east), W. (West); Hennepin avenue to Su-
perior avenue is the dividing line between north and south and Nicollet avenue
from Grant street, the dividing line between east and west in W. D.
All streets south of Grant street, Ken wood Parkway and Superior avenue and
running parallel therewith are designated E. when east of Nicollet avenue_and
W. when west of Nicollet avenue, while the avenues are all designated S. From
Hennepin avenue up the river is N., and from Hennepin avenue down the river S.
Streets and avenues above Hennepin avenue are designated N. (north), and
those below as S. (south). The same system pertains to the E. D. up and down
the river, except numeral streets and avenues, which are marked Ñ. E. above
Central avenue and S. E. below Central avenue. The streets and avenues are
distinguished in E. D. thus: S. E. 2d st.; N. E. 2d st.; 1st av. N. E.; 1st av. S. E.
Numeral streets in W. D. south of Hennepin avenue are designated S. from S.
1st to Grant st., they are then east and west of Nicollet avenue to 54th street.
For example, E. 14th st. and W. 14th st., etc.
Numeral streets and avenues have a regular system of numbering, 100 being
allowed to each block. For example, 600 1st avenue N. would be cor. of N. 6th
st.; 729 1st avenue S., between S. 7th and 8th streets and near 8th street, and 600
S. 1st st., corner 6th avenue S.; 100 N. 6th street, corner 1st avenue N.; 100 E. 14th
street, corner 1st avenue S.; 1300 E. 24th street, corner 13th avenue S.
Central avenue and Division street are the dividing line in the E. D. between
N. E. and S. E. with the regular system of numbering on all numeral streets
and avenues.

21st av S. Organized 1869. (9,500 vol-
umes) Librarian, Prof. Wm. Mills. The
library is for the use of the seminary

Eggleston; Sec., F. A. Chamberlain; Di-
rectors, Dr. A. C. Fairbairn, J. R. King-
man and R. M. Bennett; Katherine Pat-
ten, Asst. Librarian. Contract of union
to endure for 99 years. Books open free

Open 8:30 a. m. to 10 p. m. On Sundays
and holidays the reading rooms and ref-
erence department are also open from 2

University of Minnesota Library-In Li-
brary building of the University. Or-
ganized 1869. 110,000 volumes. Librar-
ian, James T. Gerould; Asst. Librarian,
Lettie M. Crafts; Second Asst. Librarian,
Ina Firkins; Third Asst. Librarian, Helen
M. Smith. The library is open to every-
body from 8 a. m. to 9 p. m. every day
of the university year, except Sundays
and holidays. During the vacation the
library is open every day from 9 to 12
a. m. For reference work the library is
free to evey one. There is a manuscript
card catalogue of authors of all books
in the library.

erence department are also open from 2

University of Minnesota Library-In Li-
brary building of the University. Or-
ganized 1869. 110,000 volumes. Librar-
ian, James T. Gerould; Asst. Librarian,
Lettie M. Crafts; Second Asst. Librarian,
Ina Firkins; Third Asst. Librarian, Helen
M. Smith. The library is open to every-
body from 8 a. m. to 9 p. m. every day
of the university year, except Sundays
and holidays. During the vacation the
library is open every day from 9 to 12
a. m. For reference work the library is
free to evey one. There is a manuscript
card catalogue of authors of all books
in the library.

21st av S. Organized 1869. (9,500 vol-

Open 8:30 a. m. to 10 p. m. On Sundays

erence department are also open from 2

University of Minnesota Library-In Li-
brary building of the University. Or-
ganized 1869. 110,000 volumes. Librar-
ian, James T. Gerould; Asst. Librarian,
Lettie M. Crafts; Second Asst. Librarian,
Ina Firkins; Third Asst. Librarian, Helen
M. Smith. The library is open to every-
body from 8 a. m. to 9 p. m. every day
of the university year, except Sundays
and holidays. During the vacation the
library is open every day from 9 to 12
a. m. For reference work the library is
free to evey one. There is a manuscript
card catalogue of authors of all books
in the library.

General Information.
Applications for missing letters, papers
and packages mailed at Minneapolis for
other postoffices, for mail matter that is
held for postage, or is for any other reason
unmailable, should be made at the Inquiry
Division. Room No. 1.
For entry of Second Class Matter or for
information concerning the same, and for
letters which the senders desire to recall
by telegraph before delivery is made to
addressees, application should be made at
the office of the Superintendent of Mails.
Room No. 1.
For stamped envelopes, postal cards, etc.,
in quantities of 500 or over, application
should be made to the Cashier, 2d floor.
For the redemption of stamped envelopes
which have been spoiled in directing or
printing, apply to the Retail Stamp Win-
dow.
For rental of lock boxes and drawers
apply to the Finance Clerk, Room No. 1.
For employment as clerk or carrier, or
information concerning the same, applica-
tion should be made to the Secretary of
the Local Board of Examiners for the
Civil Service Commission, Room No. 1.
Penalty for Evasion of Payment of Post-
age Any person who shall conceal or in-
close matter of a higher class in that of
a lower class, and deposit, or cause the
same to be deposited, for conveyance by
mail at a less rate than would be charged
for such higher class matter, shall for
every offense be liable to a penalty of
$10.00.
Detention, wrong delivery or loss of mail
matter should be reported immediately in
person or by letter to the Inquiry Di-
vision. The complaint should be accom-
panied, if possible, by the envelope, wrap-
per or postal card, in order that an ex-
amination may be made of the address and
postmarks, which is essential to satisfac-
tory results.

General Information.
Applications for missing letters, papers
and packages mailed at Minneapolis for
other postoffices, for mail matter that is
held for postage, or is for any other reason
unmailable, should be made at the Inquiry
Division. Room No. 1.
For entry of Second Class Matter or for
information concerning the same, and for
letters which the senders desire to recall
by telegraph before delivery is made to
addressees, application should be made at
the office of the Superintendent of Mails.
Room No. 1.
For stamped envelopes, postal cards, etc.,
in quantities of 500 or over, application
should be made to the Cashier, 2d floor.
For the redemption of stamped envelopes
which have been spoiled in directing or
printing, apply to the Retail Stamp Win-
dow.
For rental of lock boxes and drawers
apply to the Finance Clerk, Room No. 1.
For employment as clerk or carrier, or
information concerning the same, applica-
tion should be made to the Secretary of
the Local Board of Examiners for the
Civil Service Commission, Room No. 1.
Penalty for Evasion of Payment of Post-
age Any person who shall conceal or in-
close matter of a higher class in that of
a lower class, and deposit, or cause the
same to be deposited, for conveyance by
mail at a less rate than would be charged
for such higher class matter, shall for
every offense be liable to a penalty of
$10.00.
Detention, wrong delivery or loss of mail
matter should be reported immediately in
person or by letter to the Inquiry Di-
vision. The complaint should be accom-
panied, if possible, by the envelope, wrap-
per or postal card, in order that an ex-
amination may be made of the address and
postmarks, which is essential to satisfac-
tory results.

General Information.
Applications for missing letters, papers
and packages mailed at Minneapolis for
other postoffices, for mail matter that is
held for postage, or is for any other reason
unmailable, should be made at the Inquiry
Division. Room No. 1.
For entry of Second Class Matter or for
information concerning the same, and for
letters which the senders desire to recall
by telegraph before delivery is made to
addressees, application should be made at
the office of the Superintendent of Mails.
Room No. 1.
For stamped envelopes, postal cards, etc.,
in quantities of 500 or over, application
should be made to the Cashier, 2d floor.
For the redemption of stamped envelopes
which have been spoiled in directing or
printing, apply to the Retail Stamp Win-
dow.
For rental of lock boxes and drawers
apply to the Finance Clerk, Room No. 1.
For employment as clerk or carrier, or
information concerning the same, applica-
tion should be made to the Secretary of
the Local Board of Examiners for the
Civil Service Commission, Room No. 1.
Penalty for Evasion of Payment of Post-
age Any person who shall conceal or in-
close matter of a higher class in that of
a lower class, and deposit, or cause the
same to be deposited, for conveyance by
mail at a less rate than would be charged
for such higher class matter, shall for
every offense be liable to a penalty of
$10.00.
Detention, wrong delivery or loss of mail
matter should be reported immediately in
person or by letter to the Inquiry Di-
vision. The complaint should be accom-
panied, if possible, by the envelope, wrap-
per or postal card, in order that an ex-
amination may be made of the address and
postmarks, which is essential to satisfac-
tory results.

General Information.
Applications for missing letters, papers
and packages mailed at Minneapolis for
other postoffices, for mail matter that is
held for postage, or is for any other reason
unmailable, should be made at the Inquiry
Division. Room No. 1.
For entry of Second Class Matter or for
information concerning the same, and for
letters which the senders desire to recall
by telegraph before delivery is made to
addressees, application should be made at
the office of the Superintendent of Mails.
Room No. 1.
For stamped envelopes, postal cards, etc.,
in quantities of 500 or over, application
should be made to the Cashier, 2d floor.
For the redemption of stamped envelopes
which have been spoiled in directing or
printing, apply to the Retail Stamp Win-
dow.
For rental of lock boxes and drawers
apply to the Finance Clerk, Room No. 1.
For employment as clerk or carrier, or
information concerning the same, applica-
tion should be made to the Secretary of
the Local Board of Examiners for the
Civil Service Commission, Room No. 1.
Penalty for Evasion of Payment of Post-
age Any person who shall conceal or in-
close matter of a higher class in that of
a lower class, and deposit, or cause the
same to be deposited, for conveyance by
mail at a less rate than would be charged
for such higher class matter, shall for
every offense be liable to a penalty of
$10.00.
Detention, wrong delivery or loss of mail
matter should be reported immediately in
person or by letter to the Inquiry Di-
vision. The complaint should be accom-
panied, if possible, by the envelope, wrap-
per or postal card, in order that an ex-
amination may be made of the address and
postmarks, which is essential to satisfac-
tory results.

COMMISSIONS AND CHARGES
REAL ESTATE.
Minimum scale of commissions and charges is adopted as obligatory:
For making sales of real estate:
On sales of $3,000 or under, 5 per cent.
On sales over $3,000, 5 per cent on the first $3,000, 2½ per cent for the excess above $3,000.
On sales over $3,000, 5 
per cent on the first $3,000, 21 per cent for the excess above $3,000.
No charge to be less than....
On sale of farms and lands sold at $100 per acre or less..
$15.00
For exchange of property the same rate as in above rules, but no agent who represents
5 per cent.
both 
parties in the exchange 
shall charge more than one commission, which shall be paid
one-half by each party to the 
transaction.
It is customary for abstracts to be furnished by the party selling, and to pay all taxes
due 
upon property. Exclusive listings 
are recommended.
LOANS.
Minimum scale of commissions and charges for making of loans adopted as obligatory.
On loans of $3,000 or less, 2
% for 3 years, 3% for five years; the minimum charge for
any 
loan being $15.00.
On loans over $3,000 and not exceeding $10,000, 2% for three years, 2% for five years.
On loans in excess of $10,000 
and not exceeding $50,000, 2% for a term of not exceeding
five 
years.
On all loans over $50,000 and not exceeding $100,000, 1% with no limit as to term of loan.
On building loans 2 of 1% 
shall be added to the foregoing rates.
In addition to the above charges the borrower shall pay the expenses of the loan, viz.:
The 
attorney's fees for 
examination of abstract, the recording of the necessary papers and
shall furnish or pay for an abstract of 
title continued to date, showing the record of the
mortgage deed. Borrower 
pays mortgage tax of 1 of 1 per cent.
The rates of commission as above set forth shall be charged upon all renewals.
RENTINGS
Commissions and charges adopted as advisory.
For negotiating and making leases when rents are not collected by agents.
1. Stores and business property, lease not exceeding two years, charge on amount of
average annual rental (3) per cent.
years.
2. When term exceeds two years, add 1 per cent of the total rental for the additional
3. Residence property, on total rent for terms of lease, two (2) per cent.
residence 
property shall 
be less than one (1) year a charge of twenty-five (25) per cent of one
When lease on
month's rent shall be made, but in no case 
shall the charge be less than five ($5.00) dollars.
4. Ground lease, term less than 15 
years, on total rent covered by lease, two (2) per cent.
When property is subject to 
reappraisal during life of lease, the charge is to be computed
for 
the full term, on the basis of the 
first five years' rental.
5. Ground leases exceeding 15 years, on the appraised value of property at date of making
lease
, two (2) per cent.
If more than one appraisal is mentioned in the lease, then the percentage is to be figured
on 
an average of the appraised value 
specified.
6. Should there be a clause in the lease giving the lessee an option to purchase the prop-
erty
, and should he avail himself of 
said option, the owner is to pay the agent commission
in full, less amount for making lease.
7. When a tenant has privilege of "renewal" expressed in lease it is to be understood
that 
the owner of property shall 
pay a commission for said renewal at the same rate as
though the lease, when first written
, had covered the whole term. This commission is to be
paid at the time of the renewal.
Charges for procuring tenants are to be made at the foregoing rates, unless there shall
have 
been a previous 
agreement with the agent that he shall collect the rent.
WHEN AGENTS COLLECT THE RENT.
8. It is understood that when the collection of rents on property is not left with the agent
for 
the full term of such lease as he 
may make or renew, he shall be entitled to charge for
any lease he may make or renew at 
the rates specified in Sections 1 and 2 of this Article,
in addition to his charge for care 
and management of the property as provided in Section
9 of this Article.
9. For care and management of property, including leasing, collecting rents, paying taxes,
a 
charge of not less than five (5) 
per cent shall be made on all collections. The minimum
commission per month, for collecting 
rentals shall be ($1.00) for the collections for any one
building.

COMMISSIONS AND CHARGES
REAL ESTATE.
Minimum scale of commissions and charges is adopted as obligatory:
For making sales of real estate:
On sales of $3,000 or under, 5 per cent.
On sales over $3,000, 5 per cent on the first $3,000, 2½ per cent for the excess above $3,000.
On sales over $3,000, 5 
per cent on the first $3,000, 21 per cent for the excess above $3,000.

It is customary for abstracts to be furnished by the party selling, and to pay all taxes
due 
upon property. Exclusive listings 
are recommended.
LOANS.
Minimum scale of commissions and charges for making of loans adopted as obligatory.
On loans of $3,000 or less, 2
% for 3 years, 3% for five years; the minimum charge for
any 
loan being $15.00.
On loans over $3,000 and not exceeding $10,000, 2% for three years, 2% for five years.
On loans in excess of $10,000 
and not exceeding $50,000, 2% for a term of not exceeding
five 
years.
On all loans over $50,000 and not exceeding $100,000, 1% with no limit as to term of loan.
On building loans 2 of 1% 
shall be added to the foregoing rates.
In addition to the above charges the borrower shall pay the expenses of the loan, viz.:
The 
attorney's fees for 
examination of abstract, the recording of the necessary papers and
shall furnish or pay for an abstract of 
title continued to date, showing the record of the
mortgage deed. Borrower 
pays mortgage tax of 1 of 1 per cent.
The rates of commission as above set forth shall be charged upon all renewals.
RENTINGS
Commissions and charges adopted as advisory.
For negotiating and making leases when rents are not collected by agents.
1. Stores and business property, lease not exceeding two years, charge on amount of
average annual rental (3) per cent.
years.
2. When term exceeds two years, add 1 per cent of the total rental for the additional
3. Residence property, on total rent for terms of lease, two (2) per cent.
residence 
property shall 
be less than one (1) year a charge of twenty-five (25) per cent of one
When lease on
month's rent shall be made, but in no case 
shall the charge be less than five ($5.00) dollars.
4. Ground lease, term less than 15 
years, on total rent covered by lease, two (2) per cent.
When property is subject to 
reappraisal during life of lease, the charge is to be computed
for 
the full term, on the basis of the 
first five years' rental.
5. Ground leases exceeding 15 years, on the appraised value of property at date of making
lease
, two (2) per cent.
If more than one appraisal is mentioned in the lease, then the percentage is to be figured
on 
an average of the appraised value 
specified.
6. Should there be a clause in the lease giving the lessee an option to purchase the prop-
erty
, and should he avail himself of 
said option, the owner is to pay the agent commission
in full, less amount for making lease.
7. When a tenant has privilege of "renewal" expressed in lease it is to be understood
that 
the owner of property shall 
pay a commission for said renewal at the same rate as
though the lease, when first written
, had covered the whole term. This commission is to be
paid at the time of the renewal.
Charges for procuring tenants are to be made at the foregoing rates, unless there shall
have 
been a previous 
agreement with the agent that he shall collect the rent.
WHEN AGENTS COLLECT THE RENT.
8. It is understood that when the collection of rents on property is not left with the agent
for 
the full term of such lease as he 
may make or renew, he shall be entitled to charge for
any lease he may make or renew at 
the rates specified in Sections 1 and 2 of this Article,
in addition to his charge for care 
and management of the property as provided in Section
9 of this Article.
9. For care and management of property, including leasing, collecting rents, paying taxes,
a 
charge of not less than five (5) 
per cent shall be made on all collections. The minimum
commission per month, for collecting 
rentals shall be ($1.00) for the collections for any one
building.

though the lease, when first written
, had covered the whole term. This commission is to be
paid at the time of the renewal.
Charges for procuring tenants are to be made at the foregoing rates, unless there shall
have 
been a previous 
agreement with the agent that he shall collect the rent.
WHEN AGENTS COLLECT THE RENT.
8. It is understood that when the collection of rents on property is not left with the agent
for 
the full term of such lease as he 
may make or renew, he shall be entitled to charge for
any lease he may make or renew at 
the rates specified in Sections 1 and 2 of this Article,
in addition to his charge for care 
and management of the property as provided in Section
9 of this Article.
9. For care and management of property, including leasing, collecting rents, paying taxes,
a 
charge of not less than five (5) 
per cent shall be made on all collections. The minimum
commission per month, for collecting 
rentals shall be ($1.00) for the collections for any one
building.

Sensible, Serviceable, Satisfactory Underwear
The Perfect Fitting, Popular Priced
Munsing Union Suits
For Men, Women and Children
In quality fine enough for the most fastidious, in cost
so moderate that they may be enjoyed by all.
Whether considered from the standpoint of health, dur-
ability, appearance or price, the Munsing Underwear
merits patronage. The yarns used are the best that can
be secured. The various fabrics manufactured are the
finest that can be produced for the prices quoted. Com-
bination suits to retail at one dollar are shaped and
finished with the same care as the higher priced garments.
The fact that people who once wear the Munsing
Underwear can seldom be induced to buy any other
kind is the best sort of evidence as to the merit of the
goods. A daily production of 20,000 garments is insuf-
ficient to supply the demand. A trial will convince you.
Whether in need of underwear at the present time or
not you ought to send for some of our doll's vests. For
children's parties, birthday celebrations, church fairs and
Christmas dolls the dainty pink or blue garments are in
great demand. You can make some little girl very happy
by presenting her with a complete set, one pink, one
blue. One vest for three two cent stamps; two vests
for five two cent stamps; a whole dozen for fifty cents.
With the vests will be sent a handsome booklet showing
illustrations of all Munsing Underwear styles for men,
women and children; also sample pieces of all light,
medium and heavy weight Munsing Underwear fabrics.
The Northwestern Knitting Co., 281 Lyndale Ave. N., Minneapolis.

Sensible, Serviceable, Satisfactory Underwear
The Perfect Fitting, Popular Priced
Munsing Union Suits
For Men, Women and Children
In quality fine enough for the most fastidious, in cost
so moderate that they may be enjoyed by all.
Whether considered from the standpoint of health, dur-
ability, appearance or price, the Munsing Underwear
merits patronage. The yarns used are the best that can
be secured. The various fabrics manufactured are the
finest that can be produced for the prices quoted. Com-
bination suits to retail at one dollar are shaped and
finished with the same care as the higher priced garments.
The fact that people who once wear the Munsing
Underwear can seldom be induced to buy any other
kind is the best sort of evidence as to the merit of the
goods. A daily production of 20,000 garments is insuf-
ficient to supply the demand. A trial will convince you.
Whether in need of underwear at the present time or
not you ought to send for some of our doll's vests. For
children's parties, birthday celebrations, church fairs and
Christmas dolls the dainty pink or blue garments are in
great demand. You can make some little girl very happy
by presenting her with a complete set, one pink, one
blue. One vest for three two cent stamps; two vests
for five two cent stamps; a whole dozen for fifty cents.
With the vests will be sent a handsome booklet showing
illustrations of all Munsing Underwear styles for men,
women and children; also sample pieces of all light,
medium and heavy weight Munsing Underwear fabrics.
